archetype_name: Family Light & Fresh: Japanese and Vietnamese Weeknights
name: Miso-Soy Udon with Tofu, Bok Choy, and Lime
description: Quick, light udon tossed with seared tofu and crisp veggies in a mild miso-soy sauce, brightened with lime and mint vibes. Family-friendly and ready in 20–25 minutes.
prep_steps: Bring a large pot of water to a boil for the udon noodles.
Drain tofu and pat very dry; cut into 2 cm cubes.
Rinse and slice bok choy into bite-size pieces (separate stems and leafy tops).
Peel carrots and cut into thin matchsticks or half-moons.
Slice spring onion (white and green parts).
In a small bowl, whisk miso paste, soy sauce, rice vinegar, honey, juice of 1/2 lime, and 3–4 tbsp water until smooth.
Optional: Warm serving bowls in the microwave for 30–60 seconds.
cook_steps: Heat 1 tbsp sesame oil in a large skillet over medium-high heat.
Add tofu; cook 5–6 minutes, turning occasionally, until lightly browned. Transfer to a plate.
Add another 1 tsp sesame oil to the skillet. Stir-fry carrots and bok choy stems for 2 minutes.
Add shiitake mushrooms; cook 2–3 minutes until tender.
Add bok choy leafy tops and most of the spring onion; toss 1 minute until just wilted.
Meanwhile, boil udon noodles per package (usually 2–3 minutes). Drain well.
Return tofu to the skillet. Pour in the miso-soy sauce; toss 30–60 seconds to coat and warm through.
Add drained udon to the skillet; toss until noodles are glossy and evenly coated. If needed, add 1–2 tbsp water to loosen.
Taste and adjust with a squeeze more lime if desired.
Serve hot. Garnish with remaining spring onion and a sprinkle of sesame seeds.
